chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.fullItemName: Scenario: Management of suspected chronic pancreatitis
Scenario: Management of confirmed chronic pancreatitis

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage a person with suspected chronic pancreatitis?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Consider urgent admission if the person presents with an episode of acute pancreatitis. For further information, see the CKS topic on Pancreatitis - acute.
  • Consider urgent referral, depending on clinical judgement, if the person presents with a complication of chronic pancreatitis.
  • Arrange routine referral for all other people with suspected pancreatitis to gastroenterology or a regional pancreatic specialist centre for confirmation of the diagnosis.
  • Consider investigations in primary care if no urgent admission or referral is required. Investigations may be helpful when the diagnosis is uncertain or to exclude other conditions:
    • Blood tests — liver function tests may be abnormal if there is coexistent liver disease or compression of the intra-pancreatic bile duct (for example by a pseudocyst or fibrosis within the head of the pancreas). Note: serum amylase level is not routinely raised, is not diagnostic in chronic pancreatitis, and testing should therefore not be performed.
    • Abdominal ultrasonography can help to exclude other conditions such as gallstones and identify signs of chronic pancreatitis, such as pancreatic calcification.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendation to refer to secondary care for further investigation is based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline Alcohol-use disorders: Diagnosis and clinical management of alcohol-related physical complications [NICE, 2010], expert opinion in a review article [Mayerle et al, 2013], and the expert opinion of previous reviewers of this CKS topic.
  • Referral of chronic pancreatitis
    • The recommendation to consider urgent admission or urgent referral is based on what CKS considers to be good clinical practice.  
    • The diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis is confirmed on the basis of the person's symptoms, an imaging modality to determine pancreatic structure (computed tomography), and tests of the exocrine and endocrine function.
  • Investigations to consider in primary care
    • The recommendation on investigations to consider in primary care is based on the expert opinion of previous reviewers of this CKS topic. In their opinion, preliminary investigations in primary care are appropriate to exclude other conditions and provide helpful information on the referral form. 
    • Abdominal ultrasonography has a lower sensitivity but similar specificity to computerized tomography in diagnosing chronic pancreatitis and is helpful for diagnosing other conditions such as gallstones. It is therefore useful as a first-line imaging modality in people in whom the diagnosis is not clear [Mayerle et al, 2013; BMJ, 2015].
